The Laus Pisonis (Praise of Piso) is a Latin verse panegyric of the 1st centuryÂ AD in praise of a man of the Piso family.
The Prose Tristan (Tristan en prose) is an adaptation of the Tristan and Iseult story into a long prose romance, and the first to tie the subject entirely into the arc of the Arthurian legend.
Utendi wa Tambuka, also known as Utenzi wa Tambuka  ("The Story of Tambuka"), Utenzi wa Hirqal or Kyuo kya Hereali (the book of Heraclius), is an epic poem in the Swahili language, dated 1728.

A Taste of Greece: Recipes, Cuisine & Culture is an illustrated cookbook coordinated by Princess Tatiana of Greece and edited by the food writer Diana Farr Louis.
The Parachute Paradox  is an award-winning memoir by the artist Steve Sabella, published in September 2016 by Kerber Verlag.
Red Cotton Night-Cap Country, or Turf and Towers (1873) is a poem in blank verse by Robert Browning.
The Tales of Ise (, Ise monogatari) is a Japanese uta monogatari, or collection of waka poems and associated narratives, dating from the Heian period.
Autumn Journal is an autobiographical long poem in twenty-four sections by Louis MacNeice.
The Throne of Caesar is a historical mystery novel by American author Steven Saylor, first published by St. Martin's Press in 2018.

The Dictionary of Welsh Biography (DWB) (also The Dictionary of Welsh Biography Down to 1940 and The Dictionary of Welsh Biography, 1941 to 1970) is a biographical dictionary of Welsh people who have made a significant contribution to Welsh life over seventeen centuries.
The Ape Who Guards the Balance is the tenth in a series of historical mystery novels, written by Elizabeth Peters and featuring fictional sleuth and archaeologist Amelia Peabody.
Spy Line is a 1989 spy novel written by British writer Len Deighton.
Fallen Angels: Six Noir Tales Told for Television is a 1993 anthology, published by Grove Press as a tie-in to the Showtime television series Fallen Angels that appeared in the fall of 1993.
Raoul de Cambrai is a 12th -13th century French epic poem (chanson de geste) concerning the eponymous hero's battles to take possession of his fief and of the repercussions from these battles.
The Lovers (Greek: ; Latin: Amatores) is a Socratic dialogue included in the traditional corpus of Plato's works, though Rival Lovers's authenticity has been doubted.

Head Smash a graphic novel by writer Vlad Yudin, artist Tim Bradstreet, and colorist Dwayne Harris.
Sole Agent is a spy novel by Kenneth Benton set in Lisbon during the Cold War in the 1970s.
Seeing a Large Cat is the ninth novel in the Amelia Peabody historical mystery series by Elizabeth Peters.

"The Colour Out of Space" is a science fiction/horror short story  by American  author H. P. Lovecraft, written in March 1927.
A Satire of the Three Estates (Middle Scots: Ane Pleasant Satyre of the Thrie Estaitis), is a satirical morality play in Middle Scots, written by makar Sir David Lyndsay.
Biterolf und Dietleib (Biterolf and Dietlieb) is an anonymous Middle High German heroic poem concerning the heroes Biterolf of Toledo and his son Dietleib of Styria.

12 Days is a debut graphic novel/global manga written and illustrated by June Kim.

Liberality and Prodigality (A Pleasant Comedie, shewing the contention betweene Liberalitie and Prodigalitie, also known as Contention between Liberality and Prodigality) is a morality play by an unknown author from c.1567.

Instructions of Amenemhat (aka "Teaching of King Ammenemes I to His Son Sesostris") is a short ancient Egyptian poem of the sebayt genre written during the early Middle Kingdom.
Five Centuries of Spanish Literature: From the Cid through the Golden Age is a popular textbook providing a selection of Spanish literature from the 12th through 17th centuries.

Dracula has been assigned to many literary genres including vampire literature, horror fiction, gothic fiction, and invasion literature.
The Joy of Gay Sex is a sex manual for men who have sex with men by Charles Silverstein and Edmund White.
The Short Reign of Pippin IV: A Fabrication is a novel by John Steinbeck published in 1957; his only political satire, the book pokes fun at French politics.
The Snake, the Crocodile, and the Dog is the seventh in a series of historical mystery novels, written by Elizabeth Peters and featuring fictional archaeologist and sleuth Amelia Peabody.
The Ananga Ranga ( Stage of Love) or Kamaledhiplava ( Boat in the Sea of Love) is an Indian sex manual written by Kalyana malla in the 15th or 16th century.

Dahl's Explanatory Dictionary of the Great Russian language was the only substantial dictionary printed repeatedly (1935, 1955) in the Soviet Union in compliance with the old rules of spelling and alphabet, which were repealed in 1918.
The Mummy Case (1985) is the third of a series of historical mystery novels written by Elizabeth Peters and featuring the character Amelia Peabody.
Mirrorshades: The Cyberpunk Anthology (1986) is a   cyberpunk short story collection, edited by American writer Bruce Sterling.
